III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section • (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by
Description the child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and
appropriate to the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 9/18, youth began attending Redford Union High and was
observed having deep cuts on her face, neck and face. On 9/20,
youth was observed having fresh cuts on her wrist. She admitted
to finding glass outside the facility and cutting herself. On 9/23,
youth arrived at Redford Union observed having fresh cuts on her
face and neck and admitted to being overwhelmed and cutting
herself. Youth found glass outside the facility ‘s door again. There
is a concern that staff did not clean up the glass outside its door
that youth used to harm herself.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Director was interviewed by phone on 9/26/2024. Director
reported Youth A is in the agency’s Supervised Independent
Living Program (SIL) and lived in a cottage on the agency’s
campus with other SIL youths. Director reported there is also a
boys’ residential facility on-site and they will sometimes break
windows. When this happens, the facility’s maintenance team will
clean up the glass and turn the soil, but there still may be some
very small pieces of glass present. Director stated she has not
seen glass outside of the cottage where Youth A is placed, but
since she lives independently, she has the freedom to walk
around campus or go out into the community unsupervised.
School Social Worker was interviewed by phone on 10/11/2024.
She reported Youth A came to school on 9/20/2024 with cuts on
her body she reported having done to herself with glass she found
outside of the door of the home where she was living. Youth A
returned to school the following Monday with fresh cuts to her
face, neck, and body and reported to School Social Worker she
used glass that was still outside of her home.
Youth A is currently AWOL and could not be located for interview.
Parole Officer was called on 10/31/2024. A message was left
requesting information about Youth A’s current location. Parole
2

Officer called back and left a message stating Youth A is AWOL
and cannot be contacted.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
10/11/2024 email from Director stating Youth A was discharged
from the program on 9/27/2024.
ON-SITE INSPECTION
On 9/30/2024 an on-site inspection was completed. No glass was
observed near the home in which Youth A was living.
Analysis The agency is in compliance as no safety concerns related to
glass being left around the home where Youth A was living were
present during this investigation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Medical, dental and mental health care
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
Description living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 9/18, youth began attending Redford Union High and was
observed having deep cuts on her face, neck and face. On 9/20,
youth was observed having fresh cuts on her wrist. Staff were
made aware of the cutting and stated they would complete an
evaluation. Youth was scheduled for an evaluation on 9/23 at 1
PM. On 9/23, youth was advised by staff that she was not to
attend school, so she ran away. Youth arrived at Redford Union
observed having fresh cuts on her face and neck and admitted to
being overwhelmed and cutting herself. Youth was taken to the
ER for medical treatment by school staff. There is a concern that
staff did not complete an evaluation with youth.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Director was interviewed by phone on 9/26/2024. Director
reported Youth A is in the agency’s Supervised Independent
Living Program (SIL) and lived in a cottage on the agency’s
campus with other SIL youths. Director stated Youth A has
recently demonstrated self-harming behaviors after which a
suicide assessment was completed, and an appointment was
3

made for a mental health evaluation with Youth A’s therapist who
works for the agency. The evaluation was not completed as Youth
A was admitted to the hospital for mental health treatment the day
the evaluation was supposed to take place, 9/23/2024.
School Social Worker was interviewed by phone on 10/11/2024.
She reported Youth A came to school on 9/20/2024 with cuts on
her body she reported having done to herself with glass she found
outside of the door of the home where she was living. Youth A
refused to complete a suicide risk assessment with School Social
Worker, so agency staff picked her up from school and stated they
would complete the assessment in house. Youth A returned to
school the following Monday with fresh cuts to her face, neck, and
body and reported to School Social Worker she used glass that
was still outside of her home. School Social Worker brought Youth
A to the administrative office and the school social worker
escorted Youth A to the local hospital for an assessment. School
Social Worker stated she has not seen Youth A since that day and
she is no longer a student at her school.
Youth A is currently AWOL and could not be located for interview.
Parole Officer was called on 10/31/2024. A message was left
requesting information about Youth A’s current location. Parole
Officer called back and left a message stating Youth A is AWOL
and cannot be contacted.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
9/23/2024 Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale Risk
Assessment Version completed for Youth A documenting self-
injury behavior without suicide intent and no suicidal ideation.
10/11/2024 email from Director stating Youth A was discharged
from the program on 9/27/2024.
Analysis The agency is in compliance as agency staff completed a suicide
risk assessment after discovering Youth A was demonstrating
self-harm. Additionally, agency staff scheduled additional mental
health evaluations; however, Youth A’s school staff brought her for
evaluation on the same date the agency scheduled evaluation
was to take place. That evaluation resulted in Youth A being
admitted for mental health treatment; therefore, the agency
scheduled evaluation was no longer needed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
4

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
